courses.description: This course aims to lay the comprehensive English language foundation needed for university studies by engaging students in multi-modal learning activities. In particular, students are guided to plan and complete an argumentative problem-solution essay and deliver corresponding presentations using research, writing and speaking skills acquired in the course. Learning topics include: identifying features of academic writing, distinguishing and presenting arguments, conducting academic research, documenting sources, paraphrasing and summarising, structuring presentations, and enhancing verbal and non-verbal delivery skills. Course-tied workshops will be provided in support of students learning. This course is compulsory for first-year students, except for those who have attained HKDSE English level 5 or above or its equivalence.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELTU1002
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

Module 1: Introduction to Academic Studies
1A. Expectations to academic studies
1B. Features of academic writing
1C. Expository vs argumentative writing

Module 2: Introduction to Academic Argumentation
2A. Standards of academic research
2B. Structure of an academic argument
2C. Understanding the problem-solution essay
2D. Selecting and pitching your topic
2E. Critical thinking and logical reasoning

Module 3: Academic Research
3A. Academic honesty (plagiarism and use of AI)
3B. Citing sources
3C. Referencing style
3D. Quoting
3E. Paraphrasing and summarizing
3F. Synthesizing

Module 4: Academic Writing
4A. Outlining your essay problem analysis
4B. Essay title and thesis statement
4C. Paragraphing and topic sentences
4D. Introduction and conclusion

Module 5: Academic Presentation
5A. Structuring your presentation  solution defence
5B. Written versus spoken language
5C. Solution explanation and evaluation
5D. Listening actively and asking questions
5E. Answering questions
5F. Stage presence and visuals

Module 6: Features of Spoken English
6A. Pronunciation and syllables
6B. Stress, rhythm and chunking
6C. Fluency and connected speech

Module 7: Review, Revising and Editing
7A. Coherence and Cohesion
7B. Editing essay drafts  Formal, objective and concise writing

courses.description: This course is designed to help students with a good level of English proficiency to learn essential academic English skills for university studies. In particular, the course will focus on the development of academic essays based on library and Internet research. Course content includes topic, purpose and audience analyses, evaluating digital source materials and research methods, summarizing, paraphrasing and synthesizing skills, proper documentation of sources, presentation practice, peer reviews and self-access online learning. Course-tied workshops will be provided in support of students learning. This is an advanced foundation course which is compulsory for first-year students who have attained HKDSE level 5 or its equivalence and is a prerequisite for Level Two and Three courses. (This course is not suitable for students who have attained HKDSE level 5\* or above or its equivalence.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELTU1001
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

Module 1: Preparing for Academic Writing
 Discussions about and features of academic writing
 The development of an essay topic
 Common organizational structures for academic writing
 Subject, purpose and audience analyses
 Planning an essay proposal

Module 2: Citing and Documenting Source Material
 Researching and documenting sources
 Identifying digital sources and evaluating their credibility
 APA formatting for citations and references
 Paraphrasing and summarizing academic texts
 Employing quotation and synthesis techniques

Module 3: Preparing an Academic Essay
 The writing of an academic introduction
 Thesis and purpose statements
 Development of body paragraphs
 The writing of an academic conclusion
 Peer review of essay proposals

Module 4: Effective Oral Presentations
 Video analysis and annotation of the oral presentation assessment rubric
 Planning and organizing a presentation
 Key language and stages of presentations
 Effective use of visual aids
 Facilitating the Q&A session of a presentation, both as the presenter and audience member

Module 5: Final Touches of an Academic Essay
 Using reporting verbs and cautious language
 Effectively integrating citations into writing
 ELTU1002 Academic Style Guide
 Creating sentence variety with coherence in mind
 Enhancing logical flow by using cohesive devices
 Common academic style problems
 Peer review of essay drafts

APPENDIX: Proofreading & Peer Editing
 Peer editing of drafts
 Use of an editing checklist

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Critical Thinking in English Language Communication
courses.description:
This course is designed for Year 1 students with an advanced level of English language proficiency (HKDSE level 5\* or above or its equivalence). The aim of this course is to facilitate their development of analytical and critical reasoning skills through the study of inductive reasoning. In particular, this course will focus on the acquisition of skills necessary for the analysis and evaluation of inductive arguments in the English language. Topics that will be included in the course include: identifying assumptions, standardizing and diagramming arguments in the English language, fallacies of irrelevance, inductive reasoning, and inductive fallacies.

Samples of argumentation will be taken from both text-based sources (e.g. op-eds, articles, essays, etc.) and multimedia sources (e.g. movie clips, video recordings, advertisements, etc.) composed in the English language, to enhance students awareness of and appreciation for argumentation techniques that are variously employed in both academic and non-academic settings.

As this is a Level 1 course requiring frequent intensive engagements with source materials, the importance of academic integrity and effective source-use skills will also be discussed.

Advisory: this course assumes the attainment of an advanced level of English language proficiency, as demonstrated by a grade of HKDSE level 5\* or above or its equivalence.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken either ELTU 1001 or ELTU1002
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Relationship between language and thought
2. Uncovering types of assumptions
3. Standardising arguments
4. Diagramming argument structure
5. Fallacies of irrelevance
6. Inductive fallacies
7. Effective source use and proper attribution

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Speaking and Presenting like TED
courses.description:
The course aims to inspire students to speak and present more like TED. The course adopts a learning-by-doing approach: students are expected to come to class prepared to share their critical analyses of TED talks and present ideas in their respective academic discipline. More importantly, students should be prepared to try out alternative ways of presenting which may not conform to the presentation norms in their discipline. Students will teach each other by:

a) analyzing the content, delivery, language, design and use of visuals in TED talks; b) presenting their critical analyses in class; c) applying the results of the analyses in mini-presentations; d) creating strategies to deal with discipline-specific norms; and
e) evaluating and giving feedback to each other.

Advisory: For students with above-average listening and speaking proficiency in English, e.g., DSE 4 or above.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students who have worked conscientiously should be able to:

1. Present a well-researched idea with both reason and emotion.
2. Use both verbal and non-verbal delivery skills to enhance meaning.
3. Deliver words with clarity and confidence.
4. Use well-designed visuals to maximum effect.
5. Be able to objectively evaluate their own and peers presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

a) What elements makes for a great TED talk?
b) Self & peer assessment skills
c) Delivery skills  verbal and non-verbal
d) Storytelling techniques
e) How to connect with your audience using your voice and visuals
f) How to organise your speech using proper transitions and signposting

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English through Performing Arts
courses.description:
English through Performing Arts is a second year course designed for students from the Faculty of Arts, and those with a keen interest in learning and mastering English through modern plays, music and other onstage performances.

This course has been developed to strengthen the written and spoken communication skills of students through a genre-based approach, with a focus on informational writing (e.g. programme notes) and reflective writing (e.g. a learning journal). Students will learn and use English through particular genres and text types found in two main forms of performing arts  theatre and music.

In this course, lessons and activities have been adapted from a wide range of authentic materials including theatre reviews, programme notes, selected scenes from films, concerts, online seminars, articles from newspaper and magazines, and a play from National Theatre Live.

Altogether the course consists of five modules, including:
a module on theatre
a module on reflective writing that accompanies the theatre module
2 modules on music appreciation
a module on informational writing that accompanies the two music appreciation modules

During the term, students will also have the opportunity to attend two guest lectures and participate in (at least) one field trip with their lecturer of the course and / or peers.

Advisory: Recommended for Year 2 students of the Faculty of Arts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Module 1a: Theatre  Understanding and Applying the Language of Acting

2. Module 1b: Theatre  Purpose, Function, Structure and Language of Reflective Writing

3. Module 2a: Modern Music Appreciation and Language  Jazz and The Jazz Age

4. Module 2b: Modern Music Appreciation and Language  Independent (Indie) Music and Culture in Hong Kong

5. Module 2c: Modern Music Appreciation  Purpose, Function, Structure and Language of Informational Writing

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English Through Film, Television, and Society
courses.description: As an alternative for Year 2 students of the Faculty of Social Science and Faculty of Arts, this course is designed to introduce students to the role of film and television in the contemporary society. Broadly speaking, it is a course that examines the relationship between cinema and television as two art forms and the society. In this connection, various genres of film and television will be covered. The course will specifically explore a) the text structures and language of the two art forms; b) the way in which those texts are produced; and c) the way in which they are consumed by critical viewers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. analyze cinematic art and conduct an in-depth analysis of a chosen film.
2. appreciate and analyze a school of thought of cinema.
3. discuss various social themes of different important films from past to present.
4. evaluate cinematic language and the key elements of a narrative film.
5. write an essay highlighting their analysis of their chosen film.
6. present their analysis of the chosen film.
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Women and feminism in the romance genre.
2. Anthologies and their themes.
3. Political satire and political thriller as a genre.
4. Academy Award nominated and winning films: what and why?
5. The role and importance of musicals.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Service-learning: The Spirit of Hong Kong

meetings.instructor: Dr. LAI CHAN Sau Hing Jose
Dr. LAI CHAN Sau Hing Jose

courses.description:
Goal:

The goals of the service-learning course are to:
1. enhance student academic learning through real-world experiences,
2. increase students sense of civic identity and awareness of Hong Kong culture,
3. nurture socially responsible future leaders,
4. support meaningful projects that positively impact communities, and
5. provide students the opportunity to holistically participate and ethically discuss a wide range of social issues in Hong Kong.

Aims:

The course aims to:
1. provide students the opportunity to holistically participate and ethically discuss a wide range of social issues in Hong Kong.
2. enhance students empathy and critical thinking skills.
3. use a whole person approach to language enhancement by strengthening students existing knowledge of English presentation skills.
4. empower students to reflect on how their actions may positively impact the global and local community in preparation for them becoming a global citizen.

Advisory: Priority will be given to non-local students and those who do not speak Cantonese. All services will be conducted in English.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will:

1. have enhanced their skills in research and problem-solving as well as developed their empathy and critical thinking skills, particularly in relation to evaluation, interpretation, categorization, reflection, and synthesis.
2. have developed their communication skills by learning how to discuss, evaluate, debate, and provide constructive feedback and advice related to a variety of different topics and issues.
3. have examined challenging social issues and honed their knowledge and skills for becoming global citizens in the 21st century.
4. be able to create and design effective visual aids including infographics.
5. deliver an effective talk highlighting their service-learning organisation or project, in the style and format of a TED Talk.
6. analyse and critically reflect on their service-learning experience using a modified version of Kolbs Experiential Learning Cycle.
courses.course_syllabus:
Students will:

1. Undergo service-learning and cultural awareness training.
2. Identify a specific project they would like to undertake taking a human-centred approach by assessing community needs and problems.
3. Spend a minimum amount of time (14-20 hours) in the community directly or indirectly volunteering or researching on their project.
4. Maintain a weekly journal reflecting on their service, any issues faced, and plans for the upcoming week.
5. Learn how to create an infographic highlighting their service-learning project.
6. Present their organisation or project highlighting their service-learning experience for audiences in the community utilising verbal, non-verbal, and visual skills learned in class.
7. Reflect on their service experience by:
a. critically thinking about how it may affect change within a larger social, environmental, and economic context
b. how their experience may have affected their attitudes, beliefs, and assumptions around issues such as privilege, prejudice, and stereotype
c. consider methods or actions which could raise public awareness and promote further public involvement.

courses.description: In this course, students of the Faculty of Arts will read different texts such as short stories, novellas and parts of novels and explore other forms of media (such as visual art, film and television). These serve as means for students to learn about some well-established critical approaches in literary theory and engage actively in discussion regarding the content and ideas in the texts, as well as the writing strategies used by the authors. These concepts in literature are universal throughout the Humanities and it is hoped that through this course, students will develop their critical thinking skills via textual analyses and that these skills can be transferred to their own disciplines. The texts and film adaptations cover different genres, cultural backgrounds and eras with topics that will focus on social change. These texts and adaptations will be used to highlight different critical literary approaches used in analyses of literature and film. Students are expected to apply these lenses to their own writing and to critically evaluate their work and the work of their classmates. Participation in class discussions of the assigned readings is crucial  which means reading or viewing the texts in preparation for each class is essential.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

* Feminist Literary Theory
Students learn how characters, especially the female characters, are portrayed and how the portrayal of female characters reinforces or undermines sexual stereotypes.
* Marxist Literary Theory
Students learn the role of class (social and economic standing) and ideology (main underlying principles) in literature as they reflect, promote, and sometimes challenge the prevailing social order. They will focus on how those in power seek to maintain that power, in part by justifying it through art and literature. They will also focus on the struggle that exists between the working class and the ruling (elite) class.
* Postcolonial Literary Theory
Students learn to read for an awareness of representation of non-Europeans as exotic or Other in literature. They also learn to focus on language to see if the colonizer's language is permanently tainted, to write in it involves acquiescence in colonial structures. Other topics include observing the identity as doubled or unstable (identify with colonizer and colonized) in literature, and also learn to be aware of cross-cultural interactions within literary work.

These topics are transferrable to various disciplines in the Faculty of Arts. These concepts are also universal in understanding the trends in humanities. Understanding them will help students develop their critical thinking and develop their use of the English language in critiquing, discussing and analyzing film and literature.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Business Communication I
courses.description: This course is designed for second-year students in the Faculty of Business Administration to enhance English oral and written communication skills required for their major studies and in professional contexts. Specifically, it will focus on helping students to develop their written and spoken communication skills for networking, writing emails, and delivering a persuasive group presentation. Coursework includes impromptu presentation and speaking, writing a professional email and presentation outline, and delivering a group business presentation. Advisory: For Year 2 students of Faculty of Business Administration only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

Module 1: Networking Communication Skills

1A: Introduction to Networking

* understand networking and how it can help you to reach your professional goals
* understand how we network in person and online
* identify goals for networking
* start a conversation and keep a conversation going

1B: LinkedIn Profile (optional)

* identify your own unique skills and describe them effectively
* create or edit an existing LinkedIn Profile
* analyze effective profiles

1C: Self-Introduction

* introduce yourself in a less than 1- minute informal presentation and highlight your qualities
* develop impromptu speaking skills
* acquire storytelling skills that can be used in speaking contexts

1D: The Follow-Up/Group Discussion

* identify different kinds of follow-up questions
* come up with interesting and effective follow-up responses
* behave appropriately in different follow-up situations

Module 2: Professional Communication

2A: Formality in Communication

* recognize occasion and formality
* identify the spectrum of formality
* understand formal and semi-formal writing
* analyze different forms of business communication

2B: Principles of Business Writing  The 5 Cs

* analyze sample business texts and language features (5 Cs)
* compose and revise messages according to the 5 Cs

2C: Writing Professional Emails

* identify the format of a professional email
* apply various conventions of professional email
* express emotions in a professional manner
* choose between the direct and indirect approach appropriately for the audience

2D: Summarizing, Paraphrasing, and Synthesizing

* summarize a passage succinctly
* paraphrase and synthesize information from various sources

Module 3: Persuasive Group Presentation

3A: Planning and Structure

* understand the structure andcomponents of a business presentation
* plan an oralpresentation: situation, audience and customer analysis
* complete an outline for a presentation

3B: Storytelling in Presentations

* utilize storytelling structures and techniques to enhance persuasion in group presentations

3C: Approach, Rhetoric, Transitions, and Data Presentation

* utilize transitionalphrases
* describe figures andtrends

3D: Visuals, Verbal and Non-Verbal Delivery Skills

* make effective use of visual aids
* understand verbal and non-verbal communicationstrategies
* apply persuasive techniques andlanguage in presentations
* handlequestions effectively

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English for Education Students I

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 703
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description:
This course is designed for second-year students in the Faculty of Education to improve their powers of persuasion through spoken and written academic English. After all, educators are artful persuaders; they must persuade students to learn, parents to trust them, and administrators about what is in the students best interest. As such, the course emphasizes an understanding and application of the language of persuasion  or ethos, logos, and pathos  as well as discussion skills, academic presentation skills, questioning skills, and the development of persuasive writing based on research. Through developing these skills, students will have opportunities to use written and spoken English as a communication tool in teaching and learning contexts.

Advisory: For Year 2 students of Faculty of Education only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

Module 1: Techniques of Persuasion
 The language of persuasion: ethos, logos, and pathos
 Facts, inferences, and opinions
 Supporting original arguments with evidence

Module 2: Discussion Skills
 Best practices and general discussion skills
 Discussion language and communication
 Enhancing criticality in discussions

Module 3: Writing Persuasive Essays
3a: Planning a persuasive essay
 Characteristics of academic writing
 Creating a persuasive essay topic
 Patterns of argumentation; arguments, counter-arguments and rebuttals
 Thesis statements
 Introductions, paragraph unity, and conclusions
3b: Researching and documenting sources
 Honesty in academic work
 Documenting sources in APA format
 Summarizing, paraphrasing, and synthesizing reading material
3c: Formal style and tone
 Vocabulary shift
 Sentence variety and complexity
 Formal grammar

Module 4: Academic Presentation Skills
 Understanding academic presentation contexts
 Presentation structures
 Verbal and non-verbal delivery skills
 Question-and-Answer session skills
 Use of visual aids and multimedia input
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Post-course questionnaire (PCQ)
2. Course and teaching evaluation (CTE) questionnaire
courses.recommended_readings: N/A

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English for Law Students
courses.description:
The course aims to ease students into legal studies by teaching students language skills to help them succeed in their legal studies. Specifically, students will be introduced to the Answer to Problem Question  a basic genre that all law students must master in order for them to demonstrate their legal knowledge and competence in their studies. They will learn to present this genre in two modalities: a written answer, and a presentation.
Advisory: For Year 1 students of the Faculty of Law only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

1. write an Answer to Problem Question by using appropriate
a) structure
b) formality
c) legal terms
2. deliver the answer in a presentation by using appropriate
a) verbal communication strategies
b) non-verbal communication strategies
c) plain language
courses.course_syllabus:
The course focuses on the Answer to Problem Question, an important genre for all law students. By focusing on the structure and language of this genre, students can be better prepared to tackle problem questions in their law classes.

The course begins by teaching students professional presentation skills, focusing on verbal and non-verbal communication strategies, so as to prepare students to effectively communicate with their future colleagues and clients.

Then students are taught how to solve a Problem Question by using the IRAC model (issue, reason, application, conclusion). They are also taught the specific method and language features of writing an Answer to the Problem Question.

Then students learn to apply the taught presentation skills to present their Answer to Problem Question, using plain English to communicate their across persuasively.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Post-course questionnaire (PCQ)
2. Course and teaching evaluation (CTE) questionnaire
courses.required_readings: Selected landmark cases from contract law
courses.recommended_readings: N/A

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Academic English for Linguistics
courses.description: This course aims to prepare second-year students for further studies in Linguistics by engaging them in multi-modal learning activities that focus on literature evaluation, including critical reading, writing, and oral presentation. Students will develop and explore ideas on linguistics topics before producing writing pieces that reflect their knowledge of these topics and awareness of disciplinary conventions. Coursework will include a range of complementary tasks such as: selecting and incorporating appropriate sources, summarising and critiquing, writing a literature review that advances a stance towards the published literature, and presenting the findings of individual literature research. Throughout the course students will be engaged in tasks that enhance their academic writing and accuracy of language use. Advisory: For Year 2 students of the Linguistics Programme only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Developing awareness of academic language

a. Using appropriate academic register, language and style in writing

b. Improving clarity and conciseness in writing

2. Using sources in academic writing

a. Avoiding plagiarism by paraphrasing, summarising, quoting academic texts

b. Revising the language of citations and references

c. Recognising the differences between different academic referencing styles

3. Literature review

a. Understanding the functions of a literature review

b. Understanding the components and structure of a literature review

c. Identifying the key linguistic features of a literature review

4. Critical analysis of the published research

a. Understanding the differences between non-critical and critical reading

b. Summarising and synthesising the published research

c. Evaluating and critiquing the published research by implementing critical reading strategies

5. Oral presentation skills

a. Characteristics of an effective presentation

b. Planning and structuring an oral presentation

c. Key language for presentations

d. Effective use of visual aids

courses.description:
English through Health Sciences is a second-year course designed for students of the School of Public Health and Primary Care from the Faculty of Medicine. This course aims to strengthen students written and spoken communication in unpacking and disseminating health sciences and specialist knowledge, for example, health promotion and disease prevention, to a general audience.

Overall, there are three parts to the course  a writing component, a speaking component, and a module on specialist vocabulary in Health Sciences. Coursework will consist of:

A writing assignment (pair work) based on students choice of submitting either a research-based project OR a grant proposal OR a health pamphlet
A seminar presentation (pair work) based on the writing assignment chosen
An in-class specialist vocabulary quiz at the end of the course
Advisory: For Year 2 students of the School of Public Health and Primary Care only.

1. Writing component (part one)  Developing a research-based project
2. Writing component (part two)  Writing a grant proposal
3. Writing component (part three)  Developing a health pamphlet
4. Speaking component  Delivering an effective health seminar
5. Specialist vocabulary in Health Sciences

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Language Awareness for Teachers 1: Listening and Speaking
courses.description: This course provides prospective teachers of English with the opportunity to enhance their listening and speaking skills in English. Specifically, it will focus on effective strategies for listening and responding in an appropriate and professional manner in academic settings. Coursework will include completing listening assignments, conducting panel discussions, and giving individual and group presentations on a wide range of topics, including those related to teaching English in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For EDE students only.
courses.course_syllabus:
List of Topics

Introducing concepts of listening

Identifying your own listening habits

- Explore key concepts of listening which will enhance students language awareness of this learning modality. Three aspects will be introduced: linguistic knowledge, genre knowledge and discourse knowledge.

- Identify students own listening habits with the aim of improving listening with focused learning

Exploring listening strategies (1)

- Explore listening problems that impede comprehension and seek ways of addressing them

- Explore a wide array of listening strategies employed by active listeners, covering pre-listening strategies, while-listening strategies and post-listening strategies.

Exploring listening resources (1)

- Identify authentic listening materials for long term self- and collaborative learning

- Learn how to deliver information to a target audience

General introduction to stress, rhythm and intonation

- Deepen students understanding of the features of spoken English: stress, rhythm and intonation

- Allow students to appreciate the appropriate use of these linguistic features for effective communication in different situations

Critical listening

- Learn how to listen for ideas, viewpoints and personal stance from authentic sources such as news documentary programmes

- Learn how to respond to viewpoints critically through group discussion

Recreational listening

- Learn how to appreciate and respond to language arts by examining the skillful use of language in creating dramatic effects as in sitcoms.

Pair Presentation

- Experience how to organise and lead a group activity

- Provide all members with a wide variety of interesting activities through which they can practice both speaking and listening skills.

Inter-class Debate

- Provide an opportunity for the class to exercise critical listening and response

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Language Awareness for Teachers 2
courses.description: This course aims to help students strengthen their academic writing skills through the process approach, as well as appreciate the intimate connection between reading and writing. Specific focuses are placed on critical reading and argumentative writing based on library and Internet research. Coursework will include (1) writing a critical article review and (2) composing a formal argumentative essay. Students will be given opportunities to revise their work after receiving feedback from peers and the teacher.

Learning topics include:

Module 1: Critical Reading & Critical Review Writing
a. Highlighting the strong linkage between reading and writing
b. Introducing critical thinking and critical reading
c. Argument analysis and critique (based on educational texts)
d. Critical review writing

Module 2: Understanding Academic Writing
a. Genre and audience analysis
b. Academic style and tone
c. Academic vocabulary
d. Advanced sentence structures

Module 3: Preparing for a Research-based Argumentative Essay
a. Formulating a research topic
b. Conducting library research and documenting sources
- APA style consolidation
- Avoiding plagiarism
c. Forming research-based arguments
- Techniques of persuasion
- Presenting and justifying arguments
- Presenting and rebutting counter-arguments
- Writing effective introductory, body and concluding paragraphs

Module 4: Polishing Your Writing
a. Writing concisely and precisely
b. Cohesion and coherence
c. Effective peer review and editing strategies

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Language Awareness for Teacher 3
courses.description: The course emphasizes self-evaluation, reflection, presentation skills, expressive reading, and collaborative discussion. Students will learn how to analyse their own performance, deliver engaging presentations, read aloud effectively, and participate in constructive discussions. The course will also help students understand the importance of providing honest and constructive feedback.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For EDE students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:

Self-Evaluation and Reflection Skills
1. Examine their performances by reviewing their recorded assessments, peer evaluations, and assessment rubrics.
2. Write/record detailed reflections using Gibbs' Reflective Cycle on their performances, analysing and identifying what worked well and what could be improved.
3. Create a specific and actionable plan for improvement based on feedback and self-reflection.

Presentation Skills
1. Deliver clear, well-structured presentation that demonstrate awareness of audience needs and understanding levels. This includes adapting content for different student levels and learning contexts.
2. Use a conversational/semi-formal English effectively in their presentations.
3. Engage and connect with their audience using personal anecdotes, examples, and questions.
4. Demonstrate effective verbal and non-verbal delivery skills to enhance their presentations.

Reading Aloud Skills
1. Identify and correctly use important pronunciation features such chunking, connected speech and sound changes.
2. Control their voice using stress, rhythm, and intonation.
3. Use appropriate facial expressions and gestures to support meaning when reading stories or educational materials aloud.

Discussion and Collaboration Skills
1. Effectively participate in discussions on educational topics, demonstrating active listening and thoughtful response skills.
2. Build on others' ideas in discussions while adding their own insights.
3. Express disagreement constructively, while supporting their views with evidence or examples.
4. Create clear summaries of the group discussions that identifies the main points and points agreed upon.
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

Self-Evaluation & Reflection in Teaching
 Importance of self-evaluation and reflection for teachers.
 Learn Gibbs' Reflective Cycle self-evaluation framework.

Engaging Audiences through Expressive Text
 Deepen students understanding of the features of spoken English: stress, rhythm, and intonation.
 Allow students to appreciate the appropriate use of these linguistic features needed in reading text in an expressive and engaging manner.
 Reflect on their performance, pronunciation, and voice techniques.

Active Listening & Roundtable Discussion
 Develop and practice active listening skills.
 Evaluate ideas, viewpoints, and personal stance from a range of topics facing educators and schools in the 21st century.
 Learn how to respond to viewpoints critically through group discussions.

Analysing & Developing Presentation Skills
 Analyse presentations of different topics / speeches and assess the effectiveness of the delivery.
 Learn how skilful use of verbal and non-verbal delivery skills can bring about effective presentation on different topics.
 Prepare engaging and relevant visual support and PowerPoint slides.
 Properly prepare for questions on their Spoken Text Analysis presentation.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Language Awareness for Teachers 4: Reading and Writing of Literary Texts
courses.description: This course introduces students to a variety of literary forms in English through the study of selected essays, fiction, drama, and poetry of particular relevance to English language teachers. courses.title: Academic Writing for Contemporary China Studies
courses.description: This course aims to develop the English academic writing skills of second-year students from the Contemporary China Studies Program. Students will develop and explore ideas on a topic of their choice before producing a series of descriptive, analytical and persuasive writing that reflects their knowledge of this topic. Throughout the course students will be engaged in tasks that enhance their academic writing and accuracy of language use. courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Professional Communications for Social Workers I
courses.description:
This course is designed for second-year Social Work students aiming to strengthen their communication skills, which are essential for effective social work practice. Adopting a genre-analysis approach, the course focuses on the critical examination of authentic texts to understand the distinctive linguistic features and structures of specialized genres in the social work field.

Students will learn the principles of professional communication and engage in the preparation of case recordings, the composition of reports for appropriate agencies, and the drafting of formal letters.

Learning topics include:

Module 1: Basic Principles of Professional Communication
- Understanding professional written communication in social work contexts
- Key features of professional writing genres
- Selecting the appropriate writing approach

Module 2: The Language of Social Workers
- Common grammar mistakes
- Sentence construction skills
- Using formal language
- Using non-discriminatory and people-first language
- The 5C principle of writing for social workers

Module 3: Formal Letters
- Key features of formal letters: Parts, format, and layout
- Writing conventions, etiquette, style, and tone
- The you approach and audience-centered presentation
- Model text analysis

Module 4: Case Recordings
- Case recordings: What, why, and how
- Structure, language style, and tone
- Writing and reporting case details
- Model text analysis

Module 5: Reports for Appropriate Agencies
- Key features of social work reports
- Components, layout, and style
- Model text analysis

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Medicine Across Cultures
courses.description: This course introduces students to a variety of medical practices from across the world. The course consists of 5 modules: an introductory module and 4 other modules covering the medical traditions of a particular culture or region. Learning materials encompass a range of written texts, including book chapters, websites, journal articles, and government reports, as well as listening resources from YouTube and TED Talks. Through these materials, students have the opportunity to learn about how different cultures approach the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of illnesses. In addition, students will also develop an understanding of socio-political aspects related to traditional medicine, such as health policy and education. Students are encouraged to critically engage with the resources covered in this course, by means of classroom discussion as well as peer commentary and reflection on Blackboard. ELTU3016 consolidates students writing skills, including the ability to write concise summaries and reports, by synthesizing and evaluating the diverse materials covered in class. This course also aims to promote learner autonomy, by providing students with effective reading strategies.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English for MBChB Programme: Medicine in the Humanities
courses.description: ELTU 3017, Medical in the Humanities (also known as Medical Humanities), has been designed in close coordination with the Faculty of Medicine at CUHK. This course is multi-disciplinary and considers how doctors and health are presented through films, images, literature, poetry and the media, and how students can prepare in a humanistic way to meet the challenges of a career as a physician. The topic list is broad, including the physician-patient relationship, narrative medicine and storytelling, intercultural communication, stereotyping in the health professions, ideas about death and dying (as they relate to spiritual beliefs and organ donation), the pitfalls and potential of integrated medicine, the management of medical information in the media and how the Internet impacts patients and doctors, amongst other topics. Particularly, the course is designed to focus on developing students skills in close reading, attentive listening, critical thinking, impromptu speaking, analyzing videos and texts, and reflective writing. There will be one assigned reading and topic each week and students should be prepared to present the texts to the class and/or engage in panel discussions about the texts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will have further developed their skills in:

1. Critical and close reading by analyzing texts in the field of Medical Humanities.
2. Analyzing the language, expression and narrative of texts, films and images concerning the history and practice of medicine.
3. Structuring and delivering short, impromptu presentations that emphasize professionalism, organization and English-speaking skills.
4. Attentive listening and critical thinking through the use of video materials, followed by tasks including reflecting and evaluating, summarizing, presenting, and writing responses.
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

 Writing Critical Responses and Summaries
 Narrative Medicine and Storytelling
 Balancing Scientific Method and Empathy
 Medicine in the Arts and Arts as Therapy
 Intercultural Communication in Medicine
 Medicine in the Media
 Integrated Medicine and Complementary Therapies (Optional Module)
 Death and Dying

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English for Architecture Students II
courses.description: English for Architecture Students II aims to further develop the English language skills of third-year architecture students in the Faculty of Social Science. This course prepares students to engage with architectural professional practices by targeting architectural writing and speaking genres, and to reflect on architectural practice by engaging them in multi-modal learning activities. Among the four language modalities, writing and speaking aspects are emphasized. Coursework will include a range of complementary tasks such as: writing a precedent study, creating project statement, delivering a studio presentation and conducting a presentation on articulating a design principle. Advisory: For Year 3 students of Faculty of Social Science (Architecture major) only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): (ELTU1001 or ELTU1002) or exemption from these courses AND ELTU2021 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Writing a precedent study
a. developing deeper awareness of complementary function of images and written language
b. summarizing and synthesizing architectural texts and images
c. expressing interpretation of a precedent in a concise manner
2. Writing a project statement
a. describing and detailing a project in a concise manner
b. articulating an argument for the project
c. development awareness of processional tone and diction
3. Conducting a studio presentation
a. articulating a vision of the project
b. employing presentation strategies such as storytelling
c. choosing descriptive language and expressing oneself in a concise and precise manner
4. Presentation of personal design principle
a. developing confidence and assertiveness in expressing views
b. articulating principles and abstract ideas in appropriate language, effective supplementary graphic material with verbal explanation

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Communicating Engineering Research
courses.description: The course is designed to strengthen engineering students skills in communicating research ideas in written and oral forms. The writing component addresses both higher-order concerns (e.g. organisation and idea development) and lower-order concerns (e.g. grammar and sentence structure) in research writing while the speaking component highlights rhetorical strategies as well as language and delivery skills needed in relevant presentations. An emphasis is placed on how ideas can be communicated clearly and effectively in an academic context. Some sessions are run as interactive workshops, where students are given an opportunity to engage actively in discussion, textual analysis and peer review. The course is particularly suitable for students wishing to prepare for a research-based final year project or pursue future research opportunities.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Research Writing in the Humanities and Social Sciences
courses.description: This course aims to prepare students for the capstone course / final-year thesis in their major study and the application for postgraduate study by equipping them with research writing skills. Students will receive language support to write different sections of a research paper and a range of research-related genres, with an emphasis on literature review and research proposal writing. With the consideration that students taking this course are from diverse academic backgrounds, the course will be delivered in the form of a seminar, allowing students to share and explore the research writing conventions in their discipline, learn from peers, as well as complete hands-on information search tasks, language practice, and textual analysis. Advisory: Preferably for students in their third year of study or above who plan to do primary and secondary research in their capstone course / final-year thesis.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Learn to Write Better! English through Great Essays
courses.description: In this course, students will read, every week, one great essay and engage actively in discussion of both the contents of the essays and the writing strategies employed by the authors. The essays cover topics ranging from the meaning of education, through questions of language and identity, to ideas about wealth and poverty, social class, cultural imperialism and politics. The authors represent different nationalities, genders and historical eras. These essays will serve as models of a variety of persuasive and argument-writing strategies including narration and description, the use of anecdotes and examples, satire, the extended definition, etc. The student is expected to apply these persuasive devices and methods to his/her own writing and to critically evaluate his/her work and the work of other students in the class. Participation in the class discussion of the readings is crucial  which means reading the texts in preparation for each class is essential.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: English through Food
courses.description:
This course is designed to reinforce the reading, writing, speaking and presenting skills already acquired by third-year students through the study of a subject both essential to our bodies and dear to our hearts: food. The content-focus of this class will include a variety of topics such as food as a symbol of culture, food in the media and in literature, and new trends in the production and consumption of food in modern society. Required readings, short videos and audio podcasts will be assigned and posted to Blackboard every week, which students should come to class prepared to discuss. In this course, students will have the opportunity to explore and document their individual relationships with food, research and write summaries of various food-related texts, and work collaboratively to devise, script and film their own original 10-minute food programme. ELTU3415 will help students to become more fully aware of food, its provenance and production, history and fads, and to understand how their own food choices are made and the impact those choices can have on society. Additionally, by strengthening their English proficiency through digital and online mediums, students will be encouraged to perceive their everyday media practices as a rich field of English language production and contribute to global discourses on food.
Advisory: This interdisciplinary course is appropriate for upper-level students from various faculties who are seeking to enhance their critical reading and writing skills while engaging in media technologies to increase English proficiency.

1. Food as a Symbol of Culture

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Essentials of Public Speaking
courses.description: This course aims to help students become more effective and confident public speakers. Learning topics include vocal variation, diction, rhetoric, formality and delivery. Throughout the course students will learn to conduct critical analyses of exemplary speeches and be given opportunities to write, rehearse, and perform informal and formal speeches using techniques they have acquired. This course is particularly suitable for students who have already attained some basic presentation skills and want to further improve their spoken English.

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Intercultural Communication Through English
courses.description:
Developing intercultural competencies is a lifelong process. This course aims to enhance students intercultural communication skills in English, while fostering global citizenship. Throughout the course, students are guided to develop the attitudes, skills, and knowledge which can facilitate meaningful intercultural communication. Students will engage in tasks such as reading, watching videos, discussions, and the analysis of intercultural dialogues to help them to become more global-minded interculturally competent speakers of English.
The main course objectives are to practice deep listening (i.e., listening for understanding), suspend snap judgments about cultural difference, and increase cultural awareness of self and others. In other words, the course aims to develop some of the core attributes that are expected of CUHK graduates i.e., intercultural understanding and sensitivity, and global-mindedness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses AND ELTU2004 or 2005 or 2006 or 2011 or 2013 or 2014 or 2016 or 2017 or 2018 or 2019 or 2020 or 2022 or 2023 or 2024 or 2026 or 2406 or 2412 or exemption from these courses
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning topics include:

1. Introduction to language and intercultural communication
- understanding language and intercultural communication
- identifying the attitudes, skills, and knowledge that facilitate intercultural communication

2. Language and non-verbal communication
- understanding, discussing, and analyzing the relationship between language, communication, culture, power and context
- identifying different types and functions of nonverbal codes
- discussing and explaining the influence of culture on non-verbal communication
- practicing intercultural communication skills in English

3. Language and identity in intercultural communication
- identifying multiple characteristics of identity
- describing the relationship between language, culture and identity
- explaining the role of identity in intercultural communication
- reflecting on ones identity and how it affects ones language use in context

4. Language and intercultural relationships
- discussing, identifying, and analyzing factors that affect intercultural relations in different contexts
- explaining the potential impact of culture in conflict situations
- discussing and presenting strategies for dealing effectively and appropriately with intercultural conflicts
- practicing intercultural communication skills in English

5. Global citizenship and intercultural competence
- identifying the traits and characteristics of global citizens
- describing ways to enhance ones intercultural competence and intercultural/global citizenry
- practicing intercultural communication skills in English

courses.subject: ELTU
courses.title: Postgraduate Presentation Skills
courses.description: This course is designed for postgraduate students who want to upgrade their spoken English and presentation skills for academic purposes. Specifically, it focuses on developing effective communication skills for tutorials, proposals/protocols, seminars, conferences and oral defence. Students will be introduced to key concepts and strategies, such as audience-awareness, the power of summary, vocal advantage, and effective delivery of well-organized content materials using visual aids. Coursework consists of oral presentations and discussion of a wide variety of academic output.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Course Familiarization - Introduction to the course structure

- teaching topics

- assessment structure

- project requirements

- resources

2) Principles and Practice - Skills and strategies in giving presentations

- reflecting on ones speaking abilities (e.g. pre-course speaking ex.)

- developing good habits of better speaking in English

- clear articulation and pronunciation practice

3) Honesty in Academic Work - Quoting, paraphrasing, summarizing skills when using secondary resources

- Referencing and giving credit where it is due

4) Seminar Skills - Planning and leading a seminar

- addressing basic requirements of the seminar

- answering basic seminar questions and objectives

- chairing a seminar

- leading and taking part in academic discussions

5) Giving Prepared Speeches - Preparing a formal speech

- Setting goals and objectives

- Understanding the audience

- Gathering details

- Summarizing main ideas

- Organizing and presenting them

- Delivering the speech

- Showing position, problem, possibilities and making a proposal

- Developing greater confidence and skills in delivery

6) Giving impromptu speeches - Understanding and meeting basic requirements

- The challenge of thinking on your feet

- Giving impromptu talk and not talking impromptu

- Practicing and meeting expectations of the audience

7) Final Speech Project in Persuasion - Putting it all together and presenting your case

- Element of persuasion: appeals and logic, evidence / support

- Structure of persuasion

- Process of developing a persuasive writing strategy

- Presenting the problem, method, solution, benefits, proposal
